:thumbsup:

What _were_ you amateurs thinking back then :P And to think we just followed you like sheep :)

Is the task version valuable? Should it be renamed to TaskDoesNotThrow and the non-async versions be removed?

The sync version should definitely be removed. The first time I saw it in a PR, I cringed. :grimacing:

Every single line of code is an implicit "does not throw", because if it throws, then the test fails.

Even TaskDoesNotThrow doesn't help you, because it would have to be TaskDoesNotThrowAsync and you'd have to `await` it. You should just `await` the original code instead. :)

body:
I, for one, liked the explicitness of being able to state that _this particular line of code shouldn't throw, and that's the test_.

Not that I use it a lot, but I do use it occasionally, so I don't think it should go.

I can certainly live without it, but I still think it adds value - not because it _does_ anything, but because it makes it explicit what is being tested.

In the end, code is read more than it's written, and as Fowler writes in [Refactoring](http://amzn.to/1gDifab): _Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand._

I've always viewed the real value of `Assert.DoesNotThrow` to be making the test code more readable (because it's [more explicit](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0020)).

You're welcome to bring in the assertion library as source (NuGet package `xunit.assert.source`), which brings `Assert` as a partial class that you can add methods to, and add back `DoesNotThrow`. :smile:

While I agree with Mark, regarding explicitness of DoesNotThrow, I believe even if a method is going to be removed from a framework it's better to make it obsolete for a few versions rather than deleting it immediately.
This is a major new release, a complete re-write. To keep all functionality and mark it obsolete would've been impossible.

Just got xunit 2.0 for the first time and this is a step back.

I agree with @ploeh -- this shouldn't have been removed. I actively used it to make it clear that assertion is not forgotten. I even had a helper method for that in dark ages of forced MSTest.

I've also used it to educate people on proper tests -- focused on one thing per test and not random set of lines where each can fail (yes, each can fail, but test should have a point).

I'm afraid we're at a philosophical point of difference.

> I actively used it to make it clear that assertion is not forgotten.

Over time, we've become convinced that a test which simply says "please don't throw" is almost never the right test. If there are no observable side-effects, how do you know any work was done?

Also, in case you haven't tried it, we have a source-based NuGet package for the Assert class, which is delivered as a multi-file partial class. That makes it trivial to bring in the existing assert library and then add whichever asserts you feel are missing.

@bradwilson 
I do see your point, so to be more specific I checked where `DoesNotThrow` is used in my code.

Here are some cases:
1. Positive validation.
   I only care that Save does not throw a `ValidationException` when fields are valid, but I don't care whether it's actually saved correctly (other tests check that).
2. Mass theory.
   Consider a decompiler. I write a lot of detailed tests on specific case. But I can also make a Theory that feeds it all methods from a bunch of assemblies, just to check if there is some unexpected edge case. I can't give a reasonable expectation for each row in this Theory -- and "not throwing" is a good indicator to see which ones should be tested more.
3. "Does it work under those conditions"
   This one is similar to the validation tests in that there are other tests for actual functionality, but you want to see if system does not fail under a certain condition. Some examples: does the action complete if MSDTC is disabled? does the action complete if it is run in parallel 10000 times? Some of them can check actual output, but sometimes you don't care much -- it should just not fail.
4. "More detailed test TBD"
   Not that great from purist perspective, but sometimes you want to get a test in, and then improve on it. This test might be non-essential/nice-to-have, or the requirements/design might be in flux -- sometimes having a not-throws is more valuable than nothing at all.

> Also, in case you haven't tried it, we have a source-based NuGet package for the Assert class, which is delivered as a multi-file partial class. That makes it trivial to bring in the existing assert library and then add whichever asserts you feel are missing.

Sure, and I can add `AssertEx.DoesNotThrow` just as easily. However realistically I can't tell juniors on other projects "you just need to get an extra class that does nothing if you want your tests to be descriptive". :)

> a test which simply says "please don't throw" is almost never the right test

Here's another counter-example: sometimes, I want to implement [`IObserver<T>`](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd783449.aspx) (for some `T`), but often, I only need the System Under Test to implement the `OnNext` method.

For the two other methods, `OnError` and `OnCompleted`, I only want to test that they don't throw any exceptions when invoked.

I agree that in general, a test that only verifies that an action doesn't throw, is a test smell, but there are cases, as for example when implementing [Adapters](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adapter_pattern), when it's the correct thing to do.

This isn't something that I do much, and I can most likely live without `Assert.Throws`, but I certainly believe it has proper uses.

Another vote in favor of keeping Assert.DoesNotThrow

The only reason is code readability & understanding intent.

another vote to bring this back.  Breaks backward compat.  The method is useful for readability.  Also, without it ReSharper can show warnings - for example, constructing an object that does not throw will warn about unused variable.

@adamralph That's a nice idea! :+1: 

... although obviously, it should be based on a sane model of _there/not there_, like a [Maybe](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/base-4.7.0.2/docs/Data-Maybe.html)/[option](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd233245.aspx), instead of null :trollface:
